awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Compute on Data Path: Combating Data Movement in High Performance Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
High performance computing enabled simulation has been widely considered a third pillar of science along with theory and experimentation, and is a strategic tool in many aspects of scientific discovery and innovation. High performance computing simulations, however, have become highly data intensive in recent years due to data acquisition and generation becoming much cheaper, newer high-resolution multi-model scientific discovery producing and requiring more data, and the insight that useful data can be mined out of large amounts of data being substantially increased. 

This project combats the increasingly critical data movement challenge in high performance computing. This project studies the feasibility of a new Compute on Data Path methodology that expects to improve the performance and energy efficiency for high performance computing. This new methodology models both computations and data as objects with a data model that encapsulates and binds them. It fuses data motion and computation leveraging programming model and compiler. It develops an object-based store and runtime to enable computations along data path pipeline. In recent years, a proliferation of advanced high performance computing architectures including multi- and many-core systems, co-processors and accelerators, and heterogeneous computing platforms have been observed. The software solution that addresses the critical data movement challenge, however, has significantly lagged behind. This project has the potential of advancing the understandings and the software solution and further unleashing the power of high performance computing enabled simulation.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported five institutions: Texas Tech University, Stony Brook University, Northwestern University, University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and HDF5 group to conduct forward-looking research and development to address data movement challenges in high performance computing systems. Throughout this project, these institutions investigated data model, programming model, runtime, and storage system methodologies to improve data motion, which in turn improves high performance computing system productivity. A large number of graduate and undergraduate students were trained throughout this project either directly via participating in this project or indirectly via courses and workshops offered. This project contributed to both new knowledge discovery and the future workforce development for the nation and our society. 

Intellectual Merit: This research created advanced solutions and new methodologies in four primary areas. First, in the area of data model, this project investigated new representations and data structures to facilitate the description and binding of data motion and computation. Second, in the area of programming model, this project investigated shared global-address-space models and developed new solutions to move computation to data and to reduce data movement across the data path. Third, in the area of runtime system, this project developed methodologies, algorithms, and tool chains to provide near-data computation. Fourth, in the area of storage system, this project developed extended object and metadata models to facilitate compute on data path. Numerous optimizations were also developed to further bridge the gap. The findings of this research have been disseminated via over 25 publications, with many of them appeared at top venues in the field, such as IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems, IEEE Transactions on Computers, International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques, ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference, IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium, etc. These publications, along with open-source code repositories, disseminated the research findings and understandings developed throughout this project to the broad community.

Broader Impacts: In recent years, a proliferation of advanced high performance computing architectures including multi/manycore systems, coprocessors, accelerators, and heterogeneous computing platforms that advance computing capabilities have been observed. The solution to addressing data movement challenges, however, has significantly lagged behind. This project advanced understandings and the solution to bridging the gap to further unleash the power of high performance computing and its enabled simulation. As high performance computing is a strategic tool for scientific discovery in many disciplines, the findings of this research can have an impact on those disciplines too. Students and post-doctoral researchers at participating institutions received intense training and professional development throughout this project. Under-represented minority students such as women students were particularly trained in this project too. The investigators of this project also contributed to the research community via serving on the organization committee of several conferences and workshops.
